cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive basic course in spoken and written French for students who have no knowledge of French: comprehension, speaking, reading, and writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: French for Beginners

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines . Students must enroll in one lecture and one tutorial for a total of three hours per week. Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability.

cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive basic course in spoken and written French for students who have studied some French, but who have not yet attained the entry level for FSL121Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory French
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL100H1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines . Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. cmCourseInfo.description: Intended for students having some knowledge of French but wishing to increase their proficiency to that of normal University entrance. Offers training in written and spoken French; reinforcement of reading comprehension and aural abilities; and an introduction to French-Canadian and Québécois cultures.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL102H1, or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines . Students must enroll in one lecture and one tutorial for a total four hours per week. Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability.

cmCourseInfo.description: Focuses on developing greater complexity in student’s production (sentence structure including subordination; verb tense and agreement; difficult sounds and prosodic fluency), and comprehension (analysis of word order-meaning relations; understanding temporal relations and thematic elements). Overview of francophone media and cultural institutions including cinema and festivals.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL121Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines . Students must enroll in one lecture and one tutorial for a total of four hours per week. Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to basic concepts of the French grammar from an analytic and descriptive point of view. Exploration of traditional grammar concepts such as subject, predicate, complement. This course provides understanding of the logic that is often hidden by the apparent complexity of grammatical rules.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Grammar, within Reason
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL121Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines

courses.name: Writing French: the Language of the Media

cmCourseInfo.description: Using current online French media, broaden your understanding of the French language; deepen your grammatical knowledge; expand your vocabulary (including idioms); review key aspects of French syntax; and fine-tune your reading skills in French. Weekly reading and writing workshops are an integral part of this course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing French: the Language of the Media
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

cmCourseInfo.description: Students will accomplish a variety of professional tasks and develop effective oral and written communication skills as well as acquire a deeper knowledge of the culture of the workplace in French-speaking communities: magazines, internet, video-clips. Emphasis on the study of professional terminology, correspondence formulae and professional practices of the workplace.
cmCourseInfo.title: French for the Workplace
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL, enrolment equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

cmCourseInfo.description: Students will accomplish a variety of professional tasks and develop effective oral and written communication skills as well as acquire a deeper knowledge of the culture of the workplace in French-speaking communities: magazines, internet, video-clips. Emphasis on the study of professional terminology, correspondence formulae and professional practices of the workplace.
cmCourseInfo.title: French for the Workplace
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL, enrolment equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 25, 2018. Day and Time Change: July 26, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the study of central themes in French artistic expression, designed to familiarize students with key concepts and vocabularies relevant to the subject. Study of modes of artistic representation, (visual, performing arts) and their contribution to the rich heritage and identity of French culture. Observation, description and analysis of various artistic mediums.
cmCourseInfo.title: French for the Arts
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test

courses.name: French Oral Communication for Professional and Academic Contexts

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for students who wish to develop their oral communication skills in French in preparation for bilingual employment, community service, and academic activities in Canada and abroad. Emphasis is placed on the development of skills for accurate oral language use in professional and academic contexts: researched oral presentations, debates, interviews, and student-led discussions. Students will learn how to adapt their speaking style and register to different audiences and situations, use appropriate vocabulary, and self-correct.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Oral Communication for Professional and Academic Contexts
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL, enrolment equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL321Y1. Not open to fluent and native speakers of French.

cmCourseInfo.description: Develops further students’ written/speaking and comprehension/listening abilities by focusing on greater sentential and lexical complexity. Particular attention is paid to norms (contextually-appropriate (in)formality; particularities of French spelling and punctuation; differences between Canadian and European varieties). Investigation of linguistic, political and cultural aspects of the Francophonie.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language III
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL221Y1 (63%) or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL375Y1 and higher. May not concurrently take FSL362H1, FSL363H1, FSL364H1.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines . Students must enroll in one lecture and one tutorial for a total of four hours per week. Students should check for any schedule conflict before enrolling in a tutorial. Changing or switching of lecture meeting or tutorial at mid-session is not permitted at the Department of French. Students who are not enrolled in the tutorial of their choice by the deadline will be placed by the Department of French in another section according to availability.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course is part of an international agreement between the University of Toronto and the University of Nice. Students will take the course in Nice.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language and Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Only students participating in the Third Year Abroad in Nice are eligible for these courses. For more information, contact the Study Elsewhere Advisor at french.elsewhere@utoronto.ca or 416 926 1300, ext. 3141.

cmCourseInfo.description: A comparative study of the characteristics of French and English expression and how they pertain to the problems of translation and an introduction to the main aspects of translation through the study of texts of varied natures and origins.
cmCourseInfo.title: Practical Translation: French - English
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 1.0 FCE in FSL at the 300-level, or any 1.0 FCE in FRE at the 200-level.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed to strengthen oral communication skills in French and develop intercultural competence for a variety of career paths including public relations, international development, federal and provincial government. Students will acquire expertise in spoken French through in-class activities supported by multimedia: interviews, professional presentations, and debates. The course is not open to fluent or native speakers of French.
cmCourseInfo.title: Professional Communication in French (Oral)
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: FSL421Y1. Not open to fluent or native speakers of French.

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced course in French including the reading and discussion of texts focussing on the francophone presence and influence in the international context. Emphasis is placed on mastery of complex linguistic skills via use of a variety of reference tools and self-correction.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Language IV
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FSL321Y1 or, upon first FRE/FSL enrolment, equivalent as determined by the French Placement Test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines

courses.name: Reading and Writing Fiction and Non-Fiction in French

cmCourseInfo.description: Hybrid course designed for students who wish to further develop their reading and writing skills in French. Through a combination of traditional classroom time and online instruction, students will acquire analytic tools to comprehend, analyze and write fiction and non-fiction texts. Multimedia approach to understanding the cultural experiences of francophone world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Reading and Writing Fiction and Non-Fiction in French

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The Department reserves the right to place students in the language course appropriate to their level of linguistic competence, based on the results of a placement test. For more information on taking the placement test and guidelines on how to enroll into our courses, please visit: www.french.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/enrolment_guidelines

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for students who wish to consolidate and perfect their speaking and listening abilities: focuses on various aspects and difficulties that come with speaking and understanding French in real-life situations. Students will strengthen their mastery of French and acquire the confidence they need for a professional environment.
cmCourseInfo.title: Oral French in Context
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Not open to fluent or native speakers of French.

notes.name: Course Note
